content.user_title: Create Custom Claude Code Agents for Task Delegation
content.value_statement: Building specialized agents for complex workflows can be challenging without clear guidance. This skill provides templates and configuration reference for creating Claude Code subagents that handle specific tasks with the right tools and permissions.

Provide templates for common agent types: researcher, reviewer, and specialist
Explain agent file format with YAML frontmatter and system prompts
Detail available tools, models, and permission modes for agents
Show how to configure automatic and explicit agent invocation
Document storage locations and priority for project vs user agents
limitations: Does not create agents automatically, provides guidance and templates only
Requires understanding of YAML syntax and markdown formatting
Agent effectiveness depends on proper system prompt design
Limited to Claude Code platform agent capabilities

output_examples.input: Help me create a code review agent
output: I will guide you through creating a code review agent. First, let me ask a few questions:
- What specific aspects should it review? (security, performance, style, etc.)
- Should it be able to modify files or only provide feedback?
- Do you want it to run automatically or only when explicitly invoked?
Based on your answers, I can help you create an agent with the appropriate tools and system prompt.

output_examples.input: Show me how to make a read-only research agent
output: I will create a read-only research agent for you. Here is the configuration:
This agent will have Read, Glob, and Grep tools to explore code without making changes. The system prompt will focus on documentation and explanation rather than modification.

best_practices: Grant minimum tools needed for the task following principle of least privilege
Include clear trigger words in agent descriptions for automatic selection
Use haiku model for quick lookups and opus for complex reasoning tasks
anti_patterns: Granting all tools to every agent without considering security implications
Writing vague descriptions that make automatic agent selection unreliable
Creating overly complex agents that try to handle too many unrelated tasks

faq.question: Where should I store my custom agents?
faq.answer: Store project-specific agents in .claude/agents/ for team sharing. Store personal agents in ~/.claude/agents/ for cross-project use. Project agents take priority over user agents.

faq.question: What tools should I give my agent?
faq.answer: Grant only the minimum tools needed. For read-only agents use Read, Glob, Grep. For modification agents add Write, Edit, Bash. Use Task if the agent needs to spawn subagents.

faq.question: How do I make an agent run automatically?
faq.answer: Include trigger words in the description field and use terms like PROACTIVELY or MUST BE USED to signal automatic invocation based on user requests.

faq.question: Which model should I choose for my agent?
faq.answer: Use haiku for quick lookups and simple tasks, sonnet for general work, and opus for complex reasoning. Use inherit to match the parent model context.

faq.question: Can I use the templates as-is or do I need to customize them?
faq.answer: The templates provide starting points that you should customize. Adjust the system prompts, tools, and descriptions to match your specific workflow and requirements.

faq.question: How do I debug an agent that is not working?
faq.answer: Check file location and naming, validate YAML frontmatter syntax, ensure description includes trigger words, and test with explicit invocation before relying on automatic selection.
